When I was in Ninth Grade, I won a thing. Â 

That thing, in particular, was a thirty dollar Barnes & Noble gift certificate.Â  I was still too young for a part-time job, so I didnât have this kind of spending cash on me, ever.Â  I felt like a god.

Drunk with power, I fancy-stepped my way to my local B&N.Â  I was ready to choose new books based solely on the most important of qualitiesâ¦BADASS COVER ART.Â  I walked away with a handful of paperbacks, most of which were horrible (Iâm looking at you, Man-Kzin Wars III) or simply forgettable. Â 

One book did not disappoint.Â  I fell down the rabbit hole into a series that proved to be as badass as the cover art promised (Again, Man-Kzin Wars III, way to drop the ball on that one).Â  With more than a dozen books in the series, I devoured them.Â  I bought cassette tapes of ballads sung by bards in the stories.Â  And the characters.Â  Oh, the characters.Â  I loved them.Â  Gryphons, mages, but most importantly, lots of women.Â  Different kinds of women.Â  So many amazing women.Â  I looked up to them, wrote bad fiction that lifted entire portions of dialogue and character descriptions, dreamed of writing something that the author would include in an anthology.

This year I decided in a fit of nostalgia to revisit the books I loved so damn much.Â  I wanted to reconnect with my old friendsâ¦

â¦and I found myself facing Mary Sues.Â  Lots of them.Â  Perfect, perfect, perfect.Â  A fantasy world full of Anakin Skywalkers and Nancy Drews and Wesley Crushers.Â  I felt crushed.Â  I had remembered such complex, deep characters and didnât see those women in front of me at all anymore.Â  Where were those strong women who kept me safe through the worst four years of my life?

Which led me to an important realization as I soldiered on through book after book.Â  Thatâs why I needed them.Â  Because they were Mary Sues.Â  These books were not written to draw my attention to all the ugly bumps and whiskers of the real world.Â  They were somewhere to hide.Â  I was painfully aware that I was being judged by my peers and adults and found lacking.Â  I was a fuckup.Â  And sometimes a fuckup needs to feel like a Mary Sue.Â  As an adult, these characters felt a little thin because they lacked the real world knowledge I, as an adult, had learned and earned.Â  But thatâs the thingâ¦these books werenât FOR this current version of myself. Â  Who I am now doesnât need a flawless hero because Iâm comfortable with the idea that valuable people are also flawed.

There is a reason that most fanfiction authors, specifically girls, start with a Mary Sue.Â  Itâs because girls are taught that they are never enough.Â  You canât be too loud, too quiet, too smart, too stupid.Â  You canât ask too many questions or know too many answers.Â  No one is flocking to you for advice.Â  Then something wonderful happens.Â  The girl who was told sheâs stupid finds out that she can be a better wizard than Albus Dumbledore.Â  And that is something very important.Â  Terrible at sports?Â  Youâre a warrior who does backflips and Legolas thinks youâre THE BEST. Â  No friends?Â  You get a standing ovation from Han Solo and the entire Rebel Alliance when you crash-land safely on Hoth after blowing up the Super Double Death Star.Â  Itâs all about you.Â  Everyone in your favorite universe is TOTALLY ALL ABOUT YOU.

I started writing fanfiction the way most girls did, by re-inventing themselves. Â 

Mary Sues exist because children who are told theyâre nothing want to be everything. Â 

As a girl, being âselfishâ was the worst thing you could be.Â  Now you live in Narnia and Prince Caspian just proposed marriage to you.Â  Why?Â  Your SELF is what saved everyone from that sea serpent.Â  Plus your hair looks totally great braided like that.

In time, hopefully, these hardworking fanfiction authors realize that itâs okay to be somewhere in the middle and their characters adjust to respond to that.Â  As people grow and learn, characters grow and learn.Â  Turns out your Elven Mage is more interesting if he isnât also the best swordsman in the kingdom.Â  Not everyone needs to be hopelessly in love with your Queen for her to be a great ruler.Â  There are all kinds of ways for people to start owning who they are, and embracing the things that make them so beautifully weird and complicated.

Personally, though, I think itâs a lot more fun learning how to trust yourself and others if you all happen to be riding dragons.
